reviewText:
The Swindle is a stealth based rogue-like heist game, being developed by Size Five Games and releasing in July 2015.  The game can be related to a combination of Spelunky and Payday of sorts.

Gameplay premise is simple, break into a house and rob as much money as you can whilst remaining hidden from guards and avoiding traps. You have 100 days to reach your goal of running a final heist run called “The Swindle” on a police station. The 100 days counts down each time you complete a heist. In between each heist you are able to upgrade your skills, equipment and purchase access to the next stage of stages.  All of your purchases stick with you right until the end, so it doesn’t matter if you die or get caught on one character, as you will just get a new one with the same skill set as before. This is my favourite aspect of any rogue-like as it always feels like you are progressing.  In each building, you will come across a variety of enemies and traps, such as mines and electric fences, and flying bots that will shoot you if you get close. You have one ability to attack said enemies, but it isn’t always easy enough to get close to them to be able to kill them.  After a couple of heists collecting smaller sums of money, you will need to upgrade your skills in hacking; this allows you to hack computers and disable traps and use them against your foes. The hacking side of the game has its own mini-game of sorts as you have to follow the QTEs on screen in order to complete a hack, fail and you will probably find your self-splattered all up the wall.

The Swindle’s art style is very steam punky. The blacks and browns suite the setting very well and lighting is also a key part of any stealth game; whilst it is only basic lighting it does its job very well. Animation of your character and enemies is really well done too, with some really smooth and fluid movements to be seen when you are jumping from wall to wall Spiderman style. Whilst the game isn’t voice acted, the sound effects are nicely done, with a lot of focus being put on the amount of sound your character makes to try and catch you out by being heard by a guard, the footstep sounds are probably the best effect in this game.

This is a really difficult game. Even the first stage of heists is really difficult and you really need to take every move you make into serious consideration. Do you break through this window now or is there a better way? Do I try and take out this guard so I don’t have to worry about him on the way out or shall I try and sneak past? Every action you take in this game will have consequences later on in the level.  The skills and equipment choices you make throughout the run will also have a huge impact as to how you play out the later levels of the game.  The last heist on the police station is essentially what the whole game comes down too, in order to unlock the last heist you have to have unlocked every other stage and have a spare £400k sitting around. If you fail the last heist either by dying or being caught, you have to make £400k again, this is often absolutely detrimental to your run as it can take about three or four heists to make that money again. If you are getting close to the last few days of your run, it will often mean failure.

As each run lasts can last anywhere between 80 and maybe a little bit more than a 100 days (you can purchase an upgrade that gives you more time), and this will take about an hour each depending on how quick you are on the heists. There is a very high replay ability factor for this game though, and one that I will certainly be keeping installed just because of the random factors you get thrown at you.  I managed to complete The Swindle on my third run and even then it was down to the last day or two of the time limit, so you really have to plan your steps carefully.

I played the game with a controller, and I didn’t have any problems controlling the game whilst carrying out the heists, I did however have a little of trouble navigating the menu screens and skills purchasing screens, it doesn’t seem to respond very well to the joysticks motions and had to opt to using the directional pad instead, minor issue though. There are a couple of graphical options you can change, but this game shouldn’t be taxing to any computer nowadays.

The thing that grabbed me initially with The Swindle would be the art style, and that remains one of the best parts of this game. Once you get past the surface of what seems to be a very samey style game to that of Spelunky, you actually have a really in-depth stealth based game that you will find sucking hours of time out of you. The high replay ability factor really pays off for this type of game, making the retail price of £11, 99 a real steal of a buy.

1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

reviewText:
The Swindle is a game about taking things that don’t belong to you. You enter a randomly generated level, try to get through without being seen, and get out with as much cash as you can carry. You don’t have to get it all, but you get a sizable bonus if you do. If you die, you lose your cash and the thief you were using and get no second chance at that map. You use that cash on a variety of upgrades like more map information, more jumps, faster hacking, bombs, access to harder map types, and smoke screens, to name a few. You get 100 days, each representing an attempt to earn enough cash to get up to the titular highest and hardest map type. 100 days might seem like a lot of time but when an attempt can less than 30 seconds if you slip up or get impatient, it starts to feel more like a doomsday clock.

The Swindle is hard. Not cheap, not random, just hard. It will punish you swiftly and severely for impatience or poor decision making. It’s hard, but not unfair.

Every single one of my several hundred deaths were my fault. I jumped too soon, I tried to squeeze in one more hit even when I knew my melee attack had a small cooldown, or I tried to overextend myself in my greed to get all the cash in a level.

New enemy types and map features are introduced with minimal tutorials, keeping the flow of the game intact and the sense of discovery a reward for the player's efforts. When you buy clearance to visit the second map type, you better have hacking level 2 or you might not even get into the building as locked doors are now a thing. You better have bombs by the third map type because some of the best loot will be sealed behind a wall. The rewards are exponentially greater as is the potential for failure.

Unlike most games that get easier as you get more tools, The Swindle responds in kind with challenges that force you to utilize those tools in split second decisions and ups the skill ceiling. If you like games that constantly challenge you from start to finish, this one is for you.

Welcome to London, 1849. Playing the role of a masterthief you hear word of an artificial intelligence device Scotland Yard is planning to deploy. Expands well starting with simple heists in the Slums district that doesn't involve more then dodging a few guards and picking up cash laying about the place (who does that!?). Gradually introducing new mechanics and smarter robots that quickly required both your platforming skills and wits. End goal is to stop the AI deployment which happens after 100 days. Heists use 1 day but if that sounds like a problem or you feel rushed, do have the ability to spend cash on increasing the timeframe.

Other primary goal of course is to increase your chances of success. Banking cash from successful heists can be spent on a range of upgrades, from simple double jumps to backpack steamjets that conceal the thieves presence momentarily. Character abilities can also purchased which included hacking tools, lockpicks, goggles that increase your general perception, bombs for blasting through walls and more. Progress to new zones is made by purchasing security clearance cards. Zones were uniquely themed and given the procedural nature levels designed quite well. reviewText:
Moonlight settles upon the cranky London skyline like dust, the light so thick it almost has heft. Tin guardsman patrol a weary route across the cool floor of the slums, their footsteps breaking the monotonous hum of billow-driven computers. Somewhere, a clock chimes forlornly.

Dandy Butterworth-Snuffpot peers down through the stained skylight, absently swinging his blackjack while planning his move. With the merest tweak of his thick moustache, he decides his time is right. He bursts through the glass - breaking the silence with shrieking violence - and strikes out with the jack to club the robot guard senseless before his feet touch the ground. Time almost seems to slow for a moment, robber and robot tumbling downward in perfect unison, hostages to gravity and fortune. Then Butterworth-Snuffpot strikes the floor, his legs snapping like twigs and his pelvis crushing into his chin.

Dandy Butterworth-Snuffpot is not the first burglar to die of fall damage in the Swindle. He won't be the last. My blushes are spared this time by poverty: I have lost little. Previously, I've lost £3,500 while leaping from a rooftop, flush and glowing from a successful heist, into the getaway pod - only to die from the fall in a comic explosion of green cash and crimson shame.

The Swindle will make you laugh. It will make you cry. It will make you angry. It will make you determined. It will make you laugh again. It might stop you sleeping. I love it unreservedly. The ♥♥♥♥♥♥♥.

The real burglar here, though, is Dan Marshall: whose latest game has stolen my imagination and, I fear, the better part of my free time. So thanks Dan, thanks.

The Swindle is a very good game, that I am very, very bad at. The Swindle requires patience, timing and skill. Traits that I am sadly lacking. But I am learning. I'm getting better.

The Swindle is a steam punk accidental death simulator in which you guide a motley crew of thieves to their inevitable demise, and each death is more hilarious or frustrating than the last. Your mileage may vary.

The overarching goal is to steal the Devil's Basilisk, an omniscient survellaince device that Scotland Yard are planning to activate in 100 days time. Each time you venture out on a heist, the doomsday clock ticks ever closer to game over. Why yes, you can actually fail in the Swindle, and many of you will do so on your first run.

Each day you will go to work, statrting off in The Slums, pilfering money from the poor London folk until you acquire enough upgrades, skills and forged documents to take on richer, and more secure locations such as casinos and banks.

The procedurally generated levels ensure that you'll never burgle the same establishment twice, although you will start to see general themes and patterns in the level layouts, every heist is a fresh and unique challenge. For the most part, the rules of each level are laid out in front of you, the enemy's fields of vision and capabilities are clear to see at a glance. Patrol patterns are consistant, and security cameras scan specific areas with precise timing. Patience is key to progression, watching for a weakness that you can exploit and then doing so will net you consistant rewards.

Interestingly, some levels may even be impossible depending on the upgrades you have acquired thus far, I'll get into upgrades a little later, but it's a very real possibility that you will be unable to 100% many levels in the game if you are not prepared for every single eventuality.

It's a risky design choice from Dan Marshall, but it highlights the problems that you will face throughout your financial reallocation career and encourages you to delve into the progression system and have a good look for tools that may help you out in the future. It also teaches you a very important lesson: Abandonning a heist is very much part of this game, in fact it is as much a part of The Swindle as any mechanic or feature.

Your thieves are not warriors, one hit, one mistake, and they are dead. Risking a gauntlet of guards, landmines and spike traps to hack one more terminal may not be worth it. Grab what you can and get out alive and the multiplier is integral to this.

For every successful heist your score multipler will increase and this nets you a juicy cash bonus at the end of every level. The more successful heists, the higher the multiplier so sooner or later you'll reach a stage where you really REALLY don't want to die. The Swindle makes you care about the lives of you little tea leaves and the exponential increase of risk/reward is the reason for this. It's a stroke of genius. Giving in to the temptation of hacking one more terminal is potentially fatal, but if it's a casino terminal worth £50k and then combine that with a triple multiplier... it's awfully tempting isn't it? Just bear in mind that carelessness and greed are your bigest enemies in The Swindle.

The problem for me however, is than in games especially, I am careless and I am greedy. I want ALL the things and even now, will try and clean out a level whether it's a good idea or not and I believe the this game has been constructed to deliberately punish gamers with that kind of impulsive habit. I love the Swindle I really do, but not necessarily when I'm in the same room as it. Sometimes I do have to literally walk away or switch to playing something more forgiving. Like Dark Souls.

Luckily, there are several abilities & tools to mitigate one's incompetance. You can unlock multiple jumps, the ability to cling to walls, a remote detonator for mines, dynamite to blast through walls and EMP device and much, much, more. Unforutnately, in it's current state, I can't recommend this game. Which is disappointing because I really, really like this game. I love the setting, the music, and the design. Please bear in mind that these problems I'm having are, for the most part, subjective.

First, the controls are not as responsive as you would need for this genre. Comparing it something like Spelunky, Super Meat Boy, or Mark of the Ninja this game, unfortunately, does not come close. Which brings me to my second point.

You don't have much control over your character. For instance, you cannot control your jump height when you're either clinging or sliding down a wall. This is incredibly important when trying to take out enemies that have been generated in an area that's difficult to get to. Sometimes the jump will accidentally put you in front of a window sounding the alarm. The controls, I feel, is the biggest hurdle for me to get over.

The randomly generated levels can be irritating. I've experienced mission 1 that does not yield enough money to get the hacking skill. This skill is what will net you most of your money in the early game and is an imperative skill to have. On more than one occasion, without being able to see the entire layout of the building in the early game, if you don't have the double jump, a triple window can really screw you over and force you to terminate your current employee and losing your XP bonus. To mitigate this, however, you could get bombs. Again, these are subjective complaints.

Lastly, I don't like that there is instant death from fall damage. Personally, I don't think this is something that's needed in this platformer, but hey, I'm not the developer.

If you do decide to buy this game, regardless, make sure you get hacking from day one. Be careful with your jump. Learn how it works and what you can do to work around it in order for you to be successful in your heists. Take your time to understand the enemies' pathing. Find the right cycle to strike and remember to be patient.

reviewText:
The Swindle is a procedurally-generated, real-time semi-roguelike solo heist game. You break into randomly-generated houses swarming with robot security guards and attempt to steal all the cash. Eventually you can move up the socio-economic ladder and break into richer buildings like banks and casinos. But it's all moving towards one goal: hack into the AI that is about to be unleashed on the city in 100 days.

There's two levels of failure in this game: You can trip the alarm, or you can die. If you trip the alarm, you get a frantic little while to scarper before the police show up. If you die, you lose all money on this heist and a day towards the deadline.

It's an interesting game. Not as refined as, say, Spelunky. The platforming is a little awkward, and occasionally the level can provide you with an impossible house. There's a nice upgrade tree that you need to climb, but probably cannot get it all before the deadline.

There's lots of great little elements. The heists themselves are neat, with steadily increasing dangerous foes. The atmosphere is great - footsteps change as you go from rooftop to floor, and the rain pattering on rooftops dulls as you go inside. And my favourite, Big Ben chimes when it hits the top of the hour in the real world!

The controls and feel need a bit of polish, but overall it's quite a neat game. It's a good colleague and counterpoint to Spelunky - a campaign rather than a run, upgrades instead of items, patience and care rather than running to the finish.

Control Option: You get to rebind the keyboard control and the controller as well plus it has deadzone adjustment for controller. The mouse isn't supported much though.

Regarding performances, prior to patch 1.04 the game tends to spike like crazy whenever something happens although that isn't much of an issue anymore and I am able to maintain steady 60fps with no issue.	Graphics	Everything as it usually is happens to be completely in 2D except for that rather jarring swinging effect which is 3D.

For most parts the game design looks good enough to pass off as 19th century steampunk Britian with short sighted robot cops patrolling within the homes of everyone but eh. Enemies and traps are easily differentiate from the background elements mostly because it has none.

Things does a get bit messy once you tripped the alarm though since EVERYTHING will be bathed in red floodlight.

The general UI received some minor improvement update but which greatly increased its usability. The upgrade screen for instance now only shows buyable upgrade with a star.

Everything also looks like it was made in crayon now that I think about it. Also if your screen looks a bit too dirty its in the option menu to adjust the dirt effect. I simply left it off because it got in the way.	Music and Game Cue	After 6 hours of listening to the music yes you will get tired of it save for 1 or 2 tracks and you might turn it off. Until you do though the song is alright for a game such as this since its not some fast pace tempo tune like you would find in MGS Rising rock theme no sir, its all tuney stuff.

Meanwhile for the sound effect, thankfully its clear to hear the enemy, hear the terminal through walls and other gameplay enhancing things. Which is might as well since enemies do have ears, least for some of them.	Controls	A bloody ♥♥♥♥ing mess if you use a keyboard even though you can rebind it, you might be able to get used to placing both hands on the keyboard but I did not.

Thankfully the controller works as well as you expected, not terrible. Full support for Xbox controller this was tested using the logitech F310 and it was nearly flawless.

Prior to patch 1.04 game was pretty hit and miss with its control and like an asthmatic cat it often cough up and cause you to freeze up, lags, glitches or straight up won't respond which has been slightly alleviated in patch 1.04. Which is to say it is less likely to murder you now and jumping no longer looks as if you are phasing through the sky 60 times per second.	Gameplay	Ok so here is the general flow I will talk about:

Pre-Mission>Mission>After Mission>Extra Note

Pre-Mission
Your designated thief is in his space craft high above the earth atmosphere powered by steam. This is where you buy upgrade, do a few shenanigans with the remaining day and where you choose which mission to go to. Since you start the game here its a good idea to get your bearing by jumping a bit.

During Mission
During the mission you will encounter guard robot, floating lamps, traps, shooting robot, security station and of course, money and terminal station.

The gist of it is that you arrive via the droppod, proceed to steal everything not bolted down while avoiding the pesky traps, camera and robot guards and escaping unscathed. Easier said than done, guards have clearly defined field of view which you must avoid unfortunately so does the camera and the floating camera and to add insult to your criminal abilities there's also listening robot forcing you to sneak past slowly.

Guards are not 1 type either, each location provides new ones differing in ability, sizes, power, endurance and speed in which they dash across the room. Not to mention those horrible traps scattered all over the place which can take a hit on both your money and health.

Thankfully you can disable/destroy the traps and guards with upgrades. Using your nightstick/baton on the robot will reduce them to an oily scrap and bombs+ hacking ensure that you will get past those traps but its not to say doing it will always give you an advantage, sometimes you will just die due to a terrible idea you thought was brilliant.

Let say you triggered the damn alarms, you have around 30-60 second to GTFO before the cops arrive and they do not mess around. Those boys in blues do not appreciate having their tea time ruined by sending overspecced police robot after you.

Say you survive all that and got all the cash and hacked all the terminal its time to get back to the droppod and GTFO of there.

After mission
Choose either to go back to the ships for upgrades or straightaway do another swindling business. The results are tallied up and provided you swindled half of the total amount it will count as a successful heist and you get more bonus the more your current burglar have more successful heist titles under his belt.

Then you use the money for more upgrades and to unlock more profitable locations teeming with tougher enemies.

Extra Note
Each heist counts as a day whether or not it was successful and you only have 100 day to complete the ultimate objective: Steal a single item from the toughest location in the game, The Police Station itself. Completely doable. [Sarcasm]

Also the world generator will absolutely shaft you in the stomach because it often gives you location with weird as heck architecture. This is the single biggest complain of mine regarding the game since you can very easily fail a heist due to the world generator itself BUT it is passable with the correct upgrades so not a total Con but still a Con.	Patches And Issues	I would have given this game a complete thumbs down had I tried reviewing it back when it first released but Dan the Dev seems pretty responsive to the community so I waited for some updates before reviewing and I am happy to say most of my grief with the game has been addressed which includes the UI, controls and general game tweaks.

The game controls wont actively murder you now and the UI is actually usable at last. The last remaining issue is still the weird as heck world generator but it seems that it is intended so I will chalk it up to a +/- case.

Master Thief

# 35 Hours

The Swindle is a pretty unique and very fun sidescroller where you sneak around procedurally generated levels and steal money so you can upgrade you abilities so that (within) 100 days/levels, you can steal an object that would render your position as a theif usless. Neutral
-You will fail. A lot.  Like a whole lot. You will have an amazing run completing 5 levels in a row, only to have everything go wrong the 8 tries in a row after that. - Dont be afraid to just bail out of the mission. It is better to get some money than none.
- Some areas are inaccessible in levels unless you have certain upgrades. Get bombs and EMPs.

This was done with a key obtained from the developer

Summary:

The Swindle is for the lover of Stealth games, and those who don't like the genre will have trouble enjoying the game for what it has to offer, due to it's lack of tutorials and punishing difficulty. There's some game design flaws here with some imprecise controls at times, but at the core of the experience, once it gets going, is a fun game where you sneak around and attempt not to get caught. When it gets going, it's pretty good, as you try to figure out the best path to make it through the level, and the randomly generated layouts can help in keeping up the variety. Those who don't want stealth are going to have a problem here, but those who love the genre, you've got a great match with The Swindle.

Gameplay Footage and Video First Impressions: http://youtu.be/j0UlR3zGLus

+:
When the game gets going, it challenges you to the best of it's ability to take a situation, break it down, and find the optimal path.
The TNT mechanic helped open up things in particular and was good for the random generation.
The stealth does feel at least at a faster pace then others in the genre at times, especially when between elements.
Good mechanics for a risk/reward regarding when you are caught, whether to stay around or to get the hell out of there.
-:
Very, very slow start. Lack of starting equipment and abilities hinders the player very early, and it can be a little bit to get “fun” while it gets up to speed. Needed to start with more then you did.
Lack of tutorials and basic mechanics will lead to unnecessary deaths in a game that has a time limit in terms of days. That's frustrating.
Inaccuracy on line of sight cones and melee range due to visuals can lead to moments where you sit there going “how did that not hit him” or “how did I not get caught?”
The procedural generation can be problematic with making elements that the player can't honestly deal with in a good fashion, like putting a mine at the bottom of a cavern for example (at least a GOOD way of dealing with it). Can also create rooms that literally have no good purpose (nothing but enemies, no cash.
Balance problem as terminals are the only worth while target. Other cash bags really don't make any big difference in the long run.
I'm still trying to figure out why falling damage is a thing in this game.

reviewText:
The Swindle is a long-form stealth action platformer hybrid and one of the best games I've played in recent history. That said I can definitely relate with the complaints that are being made in the majority of the negative reviews. Those are:
-Wonky controls
-Impossible levels
-Inconsistent glitches
From what I can tell, The Swindle was built with the same controls design as Gun Monkeys... and quite frankly that was my biggest gripe with Size Five's previous title. These are definitely not your typical controls and it'll take you some time to get the hang of them and understand them. My biggest frustration was figuring out that when you stand close to an edge and turn around you end up sliding down the wall, resulting in many unfortunate alarms being set off without knowing why until you figure out this mechanic. Second biggest was learning the rules of mounting a wall from below. For some reason just colliding with the bottom corner is not enough to hang on but jumping directly underneath it while facing it is. It's inconsistent but it works. And that's the thing, while not intuitive it was built by design and it is a clever way of mounting a wall (although I'd prefer to push down to slide down it like every other game)... it's just you have to figure it out by yourself that that was built into the code and I can see why that would put off a lot of newcomers. As for me, it didn't take long to get the feel for things and I was able to feel in control in no time. I would suggest that there be some kind of tutorial that forces you to learn these things so that you don't go in blind not knowing the controls of the game. There are plenty of puzzles a game should present, what your controls are should not be one of them.

Being procedurally generated instantly brings on more scrutiny about fairness and with this game it's definitely easy to pass it off as short-sighted in design when in the first level you can sometimes only get 1 lousy percent of the loot because you don't have any of the upgrades needed to do certain puzzles yet. With the time restraint of 100 days, each day you lose to a lousy RNG dice roll seems like quite the unfair price to pay. I couldn't say whether or not it actually is always possible to beat the whole game despite the seed you have as that would take a lot more meticulous research of the game's underlying code to determine that but I can say that more often than not the levels are fairly generated and it's just you not doing well that's the real issue. Again, for someone new to the game, this will probably push you the wrong way and might make you feel like it's not worth the time but for me, I like a game that spits in my face and calls me mean names and waves in my face my flaws and that I could and should do better. I like to be pushed and be given levels that rub in my face that my upgrade path I've chosen was the wrong one. It's brutal and not very nice but in the end I play games for the challenge of figuring out how to beat it and The Swindle by design is a puzzle to figure out in every inch of it.

Now there are against-the-grain design choices, and then there are is just plain broken. Climbing a wall and having an enemy's sightline clip through and set off all the alarms is just not fun. Being clearly behind an enemy that doesn't spontaneously turn around suddenly turn around without cause... is not fun. But these bugs are few and far between and I imagine they'll get cleaned up.

The game is playable by all my standards and the bugs aren't bad enough that I shy away from itching for more. Losing your cover in a heist is not the worst thing to happen, the game let's slip ups and bad level generations happen and you can still pull of the final swindle with time to spare. It is brutal in the sense that you can lose 10-15 minutes of your time if you screw up at the end of a lucrative heist but you don't lose the game, something that Spelunky tended to relish in doing.

That's what I love about The Swindle though, it makes each successful heist count big time and each one that you do in succession count even higher. The game expects you to die and so when you don't you feel like a god and the game let's you relish in it. By design, this game was meant to be for those who wanted to dive deep into it and learn it's nitty gritties and tell you to go grow up if you don't. It's a bold move for sure but I love it.

So should you buy it? Depends on if you are going to take the time and have the patience to get to know it. This is not a game for those that are easily put off by failure. You'll be frustrated with it and want to kick it across the room plenty of times but as a result when you do pull off that final swindle the reward is much more grand and delicious.

I really like this game.  I'm terrible at it, but I really like it.  It's a roguelite with a steampunk asthetic, and procedually generated maps.  You're going to fail a lot to start, which is half the point? You'll get better, you should not be able to win your first try.

A great mix of Spelunky, skill trees, stealth and steampunk! You have 100 days to gear up for the big heist by breaking into buildings to hack computers to steal money in order to buy upgrades to help you circumvent the increasily secure buildings with a variety of new enemies at every turn. The levels are procedurally generated so you have to be equipped to handle any number of situations.

It's a tough game that will require multiple play throughs because you have to learn about all the new obstacles and enemies as you encounter them and as you're figuring out the systems you're rapidly running out of time. I barely made it to the 3rd area" in my first run before I ran out of time and had to start over again.

But as you improve it's a lot of fun trying to get that one really strong run where you're figuring out the best way to most efficiently purchase upgrades while also unlocking new areas. Do you save up for a new tool or do you risk going to the next area knowing that hacking even one computer will give you more money than three computers from the previous area?

I still haven't beat it but I've come oh so close and happily started a new game hoping that the next run would be better. If you're looking to beat a game in one sitting this isn't for you. But if you want to play a game that you gradually get better at playing and optimizing how you unlock your skill tree as you play then by all means play this game!

Once you get into the groove of successful heists it's very easy to get into the "one more try" mentality and easily burn away hours at a time."

reviewText:
I could swear I already wrote my review for this game. It must have un-reviewed it when I refunded it.

The game claims to be a very difficult roguelike stealth game. What it turned out to be for me was a poorly designed action platformer with unresponsive controls and little to no room for creative problem solving or advancement through mastery.

The levels are procedural, but rarely-if ever- will you see something that you didn't see your first time through a given map type. While the levels do branch, they branch like the roots of a tree: splintering off into an eventual dead-end, offering you the chance to backtrack -a lot- instead of providing alternate routes through a level.

Progression through these levels is so harshly gated by ability unlocks that it feels like a metroidvania more than a roguelike. Your abilities don't HELP you solve difficult problems, they simply decide if you can solve the problem or not. You see that branch of the level with LITERALLY NO ENTRANCES beneath you? Better already have teleport or explosives at your disposal, because there’s -no- other way to get to that  room (and the loot therein) on foot and no coming back to specific levels after you leave. This might be less frustrating if abilities unlocks were somehow tied to player skill, instead of simply purchased with the currency that you grind/collect at a infuriatingly slow pace on each level.

About the currency collection: It’s incredibly frustrating. Money is easy to get and hard to keep, as any loot a character has when they die evaporates with the character. An understandable mechanic, weighing the risk of death against the allure of additional treasure, but that relationship falls the pieces when the character is killed so often, and so quickly, by things they can't control:
-Jump button doesn't jump and land in spikes.
-Attack fails to register and the guard turns around and kills you.
-Wall jump is misaligned by a few pixels and you jump out a window.
-Get stuck in a portion of the level that is INESCAPABLE.
The game is rife with bugs and design flaws large enough that paired with the level of punishment for each player death it turns money collection into a slog.

I guess my statement about skill in regard to skill usage carried a sentiment that can be applied to gameplay as a whole. It would be far more tolerable if skill played a larger role in it. The only skill (other than winning arguments with the awkward and unresponsive controls) that I found useful was patience. Not once did I run into a situation who's solution wasn't immediately apparent, instead the majority of situations I encountered were instead challenging because their solution was (while obvious) tedious to solve, and the same as the 14 before it.

When compared to other any other modern game in either genre that the Swindle claims to be part of, stealth games, or roguelikes/roguelike platformers, The Swindle's lack of refined design, nuanced gameplay, and functional controls stand out like sore thumbs.

Also there's no room for any stealth in the game by the way. No sound or light mechanics, enemy guard have a sight line of only a few units, and there is liitle to no way to sneak" past guards. You just wait for them to turn around and hit them with your hitting stick.

I will say the game looks and sounds very nice
date: which it should considering how resource heavy it is.\n\nWait for an 80% off sale and decide for yourselves
recommended: but I wouldn't give this game away. It sullies the roguelike and stealth genres in my opinion."

The Swindle is a Steam-Punk Stealth game that's genuinely difficult in the best way.

The difficulty comes not just from the randomly generated levels or the way the guards move, but also from the time limit - only 100 days (missions) to reach the end. The characters and their names are also randomly generated, with a lot of random elements. The game's art looks great, artist Michael Firman has done a great job creating a sense of atmosphere that really goes with the music to make a really great take on a steampunk London.

I definitely recommend this game

reviewText:
If you've ever wanted to play as a victorian cat burglar who hacks steam powered computers whilst evading a variety of different steambot guards then this game is for you!
Being (or at least drawing heavily from depending on your interpretation) a roguelike does mean you will die. You'll be beaten by guards, you'll be shocked by generators, you'll set off alarms and be crushed by the security shutters and you'll misjudge distance and fall off the roof.

The combination of procedurally generated levels and difficulty scaling (though new areas and new enemies) really comes together in making you use the most of your skills and tools. With your increasing income from successful heists you get access to more powerful tools to increase your options in facing the more secure venues.

The tools and upgrades themselves are all useful, from remotely detonating mines from a safe distance to being shrouded in steam for several seconds to evade a patrolling steambot. There are a lot of different enemies in the game and with each new area you unlock you'll find a large amount of new enemies that ensure you have to adapt your playstyle to get all that sweet cash.

Lastly the art and atmosphere is really pretty with each area having a distinctive style, not to mention all the little touches like when the grime and moisture effects on the screen (that thankfully don't go too far and obstruct your vision).

This game, what it tries to do? Wonderful.

Tries, being the keyword. More often than not the controls are sluggish, your character doesn't respond. There's no way to easily fall off the edge of a ledge, instead prompting you to begin sliding down it - which is ruinous for most runs.

You can be having a perfectly fine run, killing all the robots as you explore the house - only for yourself to realize that every computer is underneath four layers of concrete, disjointed from each other - which effectively makes the level entirely worthless because Computers are the main way you net cash. Thank you random generation!

The start of the game is -very- rough, where if you don't do the first area for at least 10 days, and buy Hacking for electrical doors, as well as double jump - you'll face many warehouse missions (I wasted six days in a row, on three different new games) where you simply cannot enter the facalities at all, or if you can it's begging for immediate death. In an effort to keep things fresh, there's lovely randomly generation - you more often than not get scenarios that are simply unbeatable, where computers are swarmed with two robots on a 1x cube, with spikes on either side of them with a camera scanning the room - and the computer to turn off said camera? Is the room directly past it. Where every window inside is guarded by a camera, that you're lucky at best if the controls work with you well enough to allow you to break through it, and jump onto a wall out of it's Line of Sight quickly enough.

This could be construded as 'They're just whining about the game being too hard!' but it really isn't. There's very simple things, and very simple mistakes that you'll be cursing at yourself over, and over, and over again - suddenly realizing you're on Day 20 with a handful of upgrades and fewer results from broken levels, half-broken controls, and awful enemy AI. Sure, I can be immediately noticed while I'm falling off the side of a window at escape velocity. Sure, the camera that saw me with less than three pixels wide of Line of Sight (It's clearly and physically marked) knew for certain there was a burgalur.

It has heart, but the mechanics just aren't there. They need to be tweaked and refined. Maybe if there's some updates? That'd be great. Before then? It's fun, before you hit your first randomly generation mission that calls for an immediate and outright alert, or death to get -anything- from, resulting in yet another wasted day.

reviewText:
The Perfect Christmas Game:

Have you ever wanted to play a game as Santa? Well, slip on your red cap; this is the game for you! Christmas is under attack, and only you can save it! The Devil’s Basilisk is an evil machine that would make it impossible for Santa to infiltrate people’s homes and deliver presents. As such, you, Santa Claus, have devised a plan to restore joy to the good girls and boys. You are going to steal the Devil’s Basilisk. Commanding your elves, or “thieves,” you will jump, bomb, and hack your way to a Merry Christmas. Also, the world is run by robots.

The Swindle’s art and music are very festive, and set the mood for some platforming action. But don’t be fooled by vision cones; it’s not a Mark of the Ninja clone. This is not truly a stealth-game. More than anything, this is an arcade game. The rigid, deliberate controls recall games in the vein of Mario Bros, and Donkey Kong. Additionally, much like an arcade game, you are most likely going to fail in your first playthrough. Christmas wasn’t built in a day, and this game is challenging. However, unlike most classic arcade games, you do not have a set number of lives before you are forced to restart. Instead, you have 100 days (referencing the song “100 Nights of Christmas”) to reach the last level, perform the ultimate heist, and save the season.

Access to the last level is expensive, so before you can win, you will need to amass money- and they only accept British Pounds. Fortunately, after the apocalypse, the British Pound was the robot’s currency of choice. Robots cannot love; surely, it is okay to rob them. Using, your Santa infiltration know-how, direct your elves through the slums, banks, and casinos, to take them for everything they’ve got. Every attempted heist costs one of your 100 days, and a successful heist will bring you money and experience bonuses Fail, and one of your elves is banished from the Winter Wonderlands- Santa Claus does not accept failure.

Have you got what it takes to save Christmas?

reviewText:
This is a great game, with a lot of polish, which is let down by a few minor flaws which unfortunately, impact the enjoyability quite a lot.

I wanna start out by saying, I really enjoy the gameplay, its punchy, fun, the controls are solid(despite a couple of bugbears), the upgrades all very cool, a diverse range of enemies/locations, and different ways of tackling each level.

However, the first thing anyone will notice is your 100 day limit, which I was first put off by. As I got into the game I warmed to the idea, even with there being no New Game+ or what not.

Heres the first issue, the start of the game is a SLOW SLOG. Its great the first time around, as you open new stuff and work out what you want, but on subsequent playthroughs it becomes more than a chore, if becomes infuriating.
You will be rerolling a lot too, as your time ticks down and you realise that there is no way you are going to make it.

This is another issue, the idea might be that you need to race to the end, but all too often you get 3/4s and just shrug and say 'bleh'. You know you aren't going to make it, and have to go through all that slog again, before you can get to the cool bits where you are nimbly jaunting around.

The main reason this feels like a slog, is due to the fact you are going to feel cheated. Quite often.
At the start it will be things such as being placed in buildings you just cant escape. Fine, you arent outfitted for it, but your only option is suicide. Its particularly frustrating when you hit two or three in a row.

The enemies will sometimes spawn in such strnge ways, and once again early on that it makes stuff impassable. Enemies that will appear on single blocks, with a mine on it also, with a camera above it. Thats one example and by far not the worst, where it feels less like you dont have the skill so much as... well there werent enough variables set up for building the levels.

It all too often also feels as if the AI bugs out, floating cameras move slowly for most parts, then sometimes will turn on a dime, in a split second.
You cant get out of the way, and thats another GG.
There is no rhyme or reason to their patrolling either, nothing you can guage, and often, you will spend five minutes just waiting... waiting for the cameras to all align.

I remember reading that the dev hated tropes of stealth games, this one is the worst, and then some. You simply cant read certain situations, and have to just sit on your hands.

The controls are fairly solid, yet then in minor places fall short. The biggest example of this is when you run into a spike pit, with a roof directly overhead. Sometimes youll make the jump, other times youll smash your double jump to oblivion and still fall in. Tbh, I think there should be a variable not allowing a spike pit in this situation, its just kinda ridic.
Youll also often find yourself in a situation where you will cling to a wall at a bad time, you are lining up a jump attack or what not, and you dont THINK you are close to the wall, then bam.

All of this mixes into a milkshake of frustration, where it steps over the line of so many Rogues before it. In all the games of this type I love, I never feel cheated, theres always something to push me to try again, and the knowledge that the next time I will progress a bit further, with the aid of extra exp, or cash, or whatever.

The opposite is true here, and the fact is you avoid going to new areas due to a lot of these things. People seem to stick to farming Zones 2/3, which once you work out how the bonuses work seems a legit strategy.
By putting a time limit on it, and not giving any boosts on subsequent playthroughs, most people wont see the majority of the game. Thats a damned shame.

I've been fairly critical here, so I want to reinforce that I really like this game. It has a lot of heart, the fact is I just dont know whether it will have enough to keep bringing me back.
The dev has said they are happy with how it stands, and have no plans for adding an unlimited mode. If I could at least aim for a mode that let me just continue to enjoy and play through the gameplay (thats really why Im here, not the story, as good as it is, sorry) I think I would be happy.

But the thought of having to do that slog over and over? Often because I feel cheated? Eh...
This is one of those games that seems like it could have done really well on EA, with a wider demo giving feedback. Im not sure how they tested this, but it feels like it is a mere month or so of tweaking/feedback away from absolute brilliance.

As it stands, its just pretty good.
